results.title: Human relations in Japan
results.brief_description: Following a typical middle class Japanese man and his family, this is an account of the importance of human relations in Japanese culture which stems from strong familial traditions and in turn effects the wider corporate and social environment. It discusses relevant Japanese traditions and terms, and uses animated diagrams to illustrate concepts.

results.title: Where we live
results.brief_description: Examines the way modern societies house their populations and the problems involved in doing so. Explores the issues involved with various forms of residential development including high rise apartments, town houses and free standing houses.

results.title: The Human image: masculinity/femininity
results.creator_credit: Kent Smith, Diantha Fielding and CBS
results.brief_description: Contemporary account of changes to gender roles and social identity. The marriage of a young couple and their subsequent struggle to make their relationship work provides continuity in a montage of dramatised and animated scenes showing the feelings, ideas, fantasies and images inherent in sex role expectations for men and women in our society. The effects of stereotyping in relationship between the sexes and in individual lives raise provocative questions for discussions. Although ostensibly challenging traditional stereotypes, the program promotes more than a few itself, eg exclusive WASP cast in the dramatised segments; no reference to homosexuality, etc. Animation: M. Borczynski.

results.title: Human heredity. - [Rev. ed.]
results.brief_description: Illustrates the basic concepts of heredity in an easily understandable context. The mechanism whereby human characteristics are passed from generation to generation is discussed. The function of chromosomes, genes, and DNA in the heredity pattern is explained. Also considers the influence of temperament, behaviour and mutation.

results.title: Human growth. - 2nd ed.
results.brief_description: Uses animation to present elementary facts of human growth and reproduction, and the differences between boys and girls in the rate of maturation. Describes the glands which control physical and sexual activity, the male and female sex organs, menstruation, fertilization, pregnancy and birth. Includes class-room scenes in which a teacher discusses questions which arise following the viewing of animated sequences.

results.title: Human beginnings
results.creator_credit: Eddie Albert Productions and University of Oregon
results.brief_description: The film opens showing a class of six-year-old boys and girls working out, through drawing and clay models, their ideas of how a baby grows inside its mother. Each child holds up their drawing and explains to the others what it means to them. The film indicates that all the children have a sound basic idea about human growth and the value of discussion with caring adults.

results.title: Human aggression (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Follows the activities of a youth gang, showing how aggression is used to assert dominance and territoriality; is provoked by frustration; and is displaced onto others. The frustration-aggression hypothesis is discussed and demonstrated in a laboratory experiment. Modifications to the hypothesis point to frustration as a key element in provoking aggression. Considers the importance of the psychological training of police who intervene in aggressive disputes.

results.title: The Hula fishermen and Koki market
results.creator_credit: Information and Extension Services for the people of Papua New Guinea
results.brief_description: Shows the daily work of men of the Hula tribe, who net and spear fish for marketing at Koki, Port Moresby. The market is shown as a social meeting place of varied Papuan peoples.
